docs.lead_paragraph: In her rusting house trailer on a patch of thistles and stones in the Mississippi River valley, Manda Seefield clearly feels embarrassment about her plight: a welfare recipient for most of the last six years. But as her words tumble out, they are tinged with anger. She knows that many Americans, including some in Congress, believe that all a welfare beneficiary needs is a stronger backbone, and maybe a swift kick in the pants. "They think we have this easy life, eating candies and watching TV all day, without a care in the world," said Ms. Seefield, 26, who collects $365 a month in aid. "They ought to come down to my level once. See what it's like to take care of kids on this kind of money. See what it's like to run into obstacles everywhere you turn."

headline.main: One Mother's Ordeal With Life on Welfare

docs.lead_paragraph: Though Congress has been arguing for months over the details of legislation to make health insurance coverage portable from job to job, the American public has no decisive view of the legislation, a new survey by the Kaiser Family Foundation and the Harvard School of Public Health shows. The legislation was passed unanimously in the Senate and overwhelmingly in the House, but negotiators from the two chambers cannot agree on important but technical issues, including what kinds of policies must be offered to workers who lose their jobs and how to impose a measure involving experimentation with 750,000 medical savings account policies with tax shelters.

headline.main: Public Lacks Strong Opinions On Health Bill, Survey Shows

docs.lead_paragraph: In the clearest signal yet that wages and salaries are moving up, the Labor Department announced yesterday that its broadest measure of what American workers receive in their paychecks rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. That was the fourth consecutive quarterly increase greater than the inflation rate. The employment cost index, which has drawn little attention until recently, is caught up in both the election campaign and monetary policy. The Clinton Administration cited it as fresh evidence that 20 years of wage stagnation was finally ending -- a contention many economists dispute. And Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, singled out the index in recent testimony as a key statistic in the Fed's deliberations over interest rates.

headline.main: Workers' Pay Rises Again, But Benefits Lag Behind

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been three years since President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, set out to transform American medicine with a plan for universal, affordable health care. And today, signs of revolution are everywhere. Health maintenance organizations are booming: more than 58 million Americans are enrolled in prepaid health plans. Three in four doctors have converted at least part of their private practice into work for the H.M.O.'s and health-care companies that increasingly control the supply of patients and the cost of treatments. Patrician medical establishments -- like Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston and New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan -- that once seemed impervious to commercial pressures are racing into mergers to guarantee their survival.

headline.main: President Finds Benefits In Defeat on Health Care

byline.original: By MICHAEL WINES and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: A longer life means a lower return to the decade-old financial industry that buys life insurance policies from terminally ill patients at discount prices and profits by collecting the death benefits. So recent breakthroughs in the fight against AIDS are intensifying the industry's search for new areas of growth, hoping to attract people with cancer and other diseases. Although reports had been circulating for months that the AIDS virus could be beaten back by new combinations of drugs, an AIDS conference in Vancouver, British Columbia, earlier this month drew worldwide attention to the development. Since then, the prices being paid to AIDS patients for their policies -- in transactions known as viatical settlements -- have fallen by 5 to 10 percent, people in the industry say.

headline.main: AIDS Drugs Alter An Industry's Math;Recalculating Death-Benefit Deals

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Researchers in a July 23 Science Times article search for reasons that women seek assistance in childbirth whereas other mammals go it alone, and contend that it is because of mechanical factors related to babies' exiting face down, a consequence of bipedalism. In fact, it is the easier and more logical route out since it follows the natural contours of the pelvis.

headline.main: Pity the Perils of the Birth Experience;Women and Childbirth

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York State Legislature concluded its 219th session at 5:28 P.M. on July 13 in a mad, confusing rush to adjournment, as Gov. George E. Pataki linked final negotiations on the state budget to many nonbudget bills. The year began with a major confrontation between the Governor and Legislature, when both houses voted to override Mr. Pataki's veto of a bill that would make it easier for New York City police officers to win larger salary increases. It was the first time the Legislature had overturned a veto in more than a decade.

headline.main: Summary of Major Actions in the 219th Session of the Legislature

docs.lead_paragraph: This is Pro Football Hall of Fame Week in Canton, an annual festival with a fine, small-town feel that includes three nights of fireworks, two parades, a downtown street fair, a hot-air balloon competition, a Marine Band concert, an Air Force Band concert, an Eddie Money concert, "the largest fashion show luncheon in Ohio," and finally, on Saturday, the opener of the exhibition season, and the big moment, the induction of five former stars into the football-shaped Hall of Fame here. The official slogan for all this activity is "Football's Greatest Week," which is such an extraordinary exaggeration if events here are compared to, say, the Super Bowl, that not even the folks at the Chamber of Commerce can repeat the motto aloud without smiling.

headline.main: Town Cheers Football And Its Volunteerism
